unnormalised: Emergency medicine in India, like anywhere else, is about rapid assessment and intervention. Someone asked about what to expect when you call 108 for an ambulance or land up at a hosp. ER in India. Well, here's a breakdown.
normalised: Emergency medicine in India, like anywhere else, is about rapid assessment and intervention. Someone asked about what to expect when you call one zero eight for an ambulance or land up at a hospital E-R in India. Well, here is a breakdown.

unnormalised: First off, understand that access and quality can vary significantly. In metro cities like Mumbai or Delhi, you might find well-equipped ambulances with paramedics who can start treatment en route to a big hosp. like AIIMS or Apollo. In smaller towns or rural areas, resources might be more limited. 108, the emergency number, is supposed to be nationwide, but response times can vary from 15 mins in urban centers to >1 hour in remote areas.
normalised: First off, understand that access and quality can vary significantly. In metro cities like Mumbai or Delhi, you might find well-equipped ambulances with paramedics who can start treatment en route to a big hospital like A-I-I-M-S or Apollo. In smaller towns or rural areas, resources might be more limited. One zero eight, the emergency number, is supposed to be nationwide, but response times can vary from fifteen minutes in urban centers to greater than one hour in remote areas.

unnormalised: When you call 108, be ready to provide key info: your location (as precise as possible), the nature of the emergency (e.g., heart attack, accident, stroke), and the number of patients. The operator will ask questions to triage the situation and dispatch the appropriate resources. Some ambulances now have basic life support (BLS) capabilities, meaning they can provide oxygen, CPR, and administer certain meds. Advanced life support (ALS) ambulances have more advanced equipment and paramedics trained to do more complex procedures.
normalised: When you call one zero eight, be ready to provide key info: your location (as precise as possible), the nature of the emergency (e.g., heart attack, accident, stroke), and the number of patients. The operator will ask questions to triage the situation and dispatch the appropriate resources. Some ambulances now have basic life support (B-L-S) capabilities, meaning they can provide oxygen, C-P-R, and administer certain medications. Advanced life support (A-L-S) ambulances have more advanced equipment and paramedics trained to do more complex procedures.

unnormalised: Upon arrival at the hospital ER, expect a rapid assessment by the triage nurse or doctor. Theyâ€™ll check vital signs like BP, heart rate, and oxygen saturation (SpO2). Depending on the severity, patients are categorized, often using a system like the Emergency Severity Index (ESI). ESI 1 is for critical patients who need immediate attention (e.g., cardiac arrest), while ESI 5 is for non-urgent cases (e.g., minor cuts). Be prepared for potential waiting times; patients with more urgent conditions will always be seen first.
normalised: Upon arrival at the hospital E-R, expect a rapid assessment by the triage nurse or doctor. They will check vital signs like B-P, heart rate, and oxygen saturation (S-p-O two). Depending on the severity, patients are categorized, often using a system like the Emergency Severity Index (E-S-I). E-S-I one is for critical patients who need immediate attention (e.g., cardiac arrest), while E-S-I five is for non-urgent cases (e.g., minor cuts). Be prepared for potential waiting times; patients with more urgent conditions will always be seen first.

unnormalised: Common emergencies include road traffic accidents (RTAs), heart attacks (myocardial infarctions or MIs), strokes (cerebrovascular accidents or CVAs), respiratory distress (e.g., asthma exacerbations), and trauma cases. Treatment protocols typically follow international guidelines, but can be adapted based on available resources. For example, if someone has a heart attack, doctors might administer aspirin 300mg and attempt to restore blood flow to the heart, either with medications (thrombolytics) or by sending the patient for an angioplasty. For stroke, time is of the essence; a CT scan is often done within 25 mins to determine if it's a bleed or a clot.
normalised: Common emergencies include road traffic accidents (R-T-A-s), heart attacks (myocardial infarctions or M-I-s), strokes (cerebrovascular accidents or C-V-A-s), respiratory distress (e.g., asthma exacerbations), and trauma cases. Treatment protocols typically follow international guidelines, but can be adapted based on available resources. For example, if someone has a heart attack, doctors might administer aspirin three hundred milligrams and attempt to restore blood flow to the heart, either with medications (thrombolytics) or by sending the patient for an angioplasty. For stroke, time is of the essence; a C-T scan is often done within twenty five minutes to determine if it is a bleed or a clot.

unnormalised: Don't hesitate to ask questions about your treatment plan. It is important to understand what is going on and what the next steps are. Sometimes, things can get hectic, but doctors and nurses should always try to explain things clearly. Having a family member present can also be helpful. Often, things can move fast, so it might be helpful to take notes on anything that you are unsure of.

unnormalised: Finances are a consideration. While government hospitals offer subsidized or free emergency care, private hospitals require payment. Insurance can help, but it's good to be aware of the costs upfront. Also, be prepared to prepone appointments or wait longer than expected because, in hospitals, emergencies always come first.
